Award.AwardTitle: REMEDIATION AND CURATION OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, RIVERSIDE COLLECTION OF APHELINIDAE (OTHER THAN APHYTIS) AND ENCYRTIDAE (HYMENOPTERA: CHALCIDOIDEA)
Award.AbstractNarration: An award has been made to the University of California at Riverside under the direction of Dr. Serguei V. Triaptsyn for the improvement of a collection of parasitoid insects known as Aphelinidae, which are important infective agents of plant pests such as aphids and mealybugs. The collection consists of some 25,000 microscope slides with a larger number of specimens of parasitoids that are dry-mounted for microscopic observation. Many of the slides are deteriorating, putting the specimens at risk for damage that would decrease their value. The project will re-mount the specimens on new microscope slides in an archival mounting medium that will preserve them for the long term. A technician and several undergraduate students will perform the work, as well as enter data on the project and the specimen collection in a database that will be made available to researchers and biological control specialists worldwide.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Aphelinidae and Encyrtidae are among the most important parasitoids of many insect pests, particularly scale insects, whiteflies and aphids (Hemiptera). Many of the species used in biological control programs around the world, including type and important voucher material, are represented in collections of the University of California, Riverside, Entomology Research Museum (UCR ERM). Because of their minute size and special drying and mounting techniques, these wasps are generally ignored by collectors and are not accumulated in most insect collections. Prior to this project, the UCR collection included approximately 60,000 specimens of?Aphelinidae (including ca. 25,000 slides, on which approximately 35,000 specimens were species of Aphytis), and ca. 50,000 dry-mounted specimens of Encyrtidae stored in 100 museum drawers and at least 8,000 slides. Both are one of the largest and diverse collections in the world and one of the few that have a worldwide scope. The majority of specimens were reared from known hosts and are irreplaceable vouchers of the past biological control projects conducted at UCR and elsewhere. Unfortunately, many of the specimens (more than 20,000) were mounted in a temporary, water-soluble medium (Hoyer's) on 5,877 slides. More than 50% of these (3,874 slides) were in various stages of decay, with the majority being completely or partially dry. Many specimens, including some type material, were already damaged. During the four years of this project, a significant portion of these specimens were re-mounted into a permanent medium (Canada balsam), properly labeled, and databased.

The considerable contributions of Aphelinidae and Encyrtidae to basic and applied research clearly justify the resources used to salvage the world's most significant collection of slide-mounted specimens of these two families. They together account for nearly half of the successful cases of biological control of insects that have been achieved through natural enemy introductions. The Department of Entomology at UCR has a historical strength in insect parasitoid research, with the families Aphelinidae and Encyrtidae in particular. Correct species identifications are impossible without a quality collection, and UCR ERM staff routinely provides identifications of Aphelinidae and Encyrtidae to various research projects worldwide. A direct impact of this proposal is availability of the identified material of many economically important species, particularly of Encarsia and Metaphycus, for comparison and study. The scientific and biocontrol communities will clearly benefit from this project through access to well-curated material (with the databased label information now available on the Internet via Discover Life site) and protection of this irreplaceable collection.

The project is now complete; it has been very successful and significantly ahead of schedule in terms of the number of specimens remounted.
